author_blurb.en: Translated for SuttaCentral by Bhikkhu Sujato, 2018. Dedicated to the public domain via Creative Commons Zero (CC0). You are encouraged to copy, reproduce, adapt, alter, or otherwise make use of this translation in any way you wish. Attribution is appreciated but not legally required.

segments.en: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of emotional barrenness.

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati.
segments.en: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence.

segments.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
segments.en: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

segments.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, ayaṃ paṭhamo cetokhilo.
segments.en: This is the first kind of emotional barrenness.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhamme kaṅkhati … pe …
segments.en: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching …

segments.pli: sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto.
segments.en: A mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.

segments.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
segments.en: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

segments.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, ayaṃ pañcamo cetokhilo.
segments.en: This is the fifth kind of emotional barrenness.
These are the five kinds of emotional barrenness.”

sections.title: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of emotional barrenness.…
